ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: definitely! very interesting class and not too much work

If you want to learn Korean, this is your only choice. It's a smaller program than the Chinese one, but Korean is much more fun to learn. It's a moderate time commitment, but any language class is, so do not let that deter you. Also, Korean is a phonetic language that borrows many words from English, so that lessens the difficulty factor.
Korean 110 is introductory Korean, so you'll learn basic Korean. You actually learn a surprising amount. It's a lot of fun, and it's a relatively chill course for an introductory language class.

I would definitely recommend KREN 110 to other students. The language is a lot of fun to learn (especially if you've never taken an Asian language before!). It takes some time and dedication, but the course/workload is neither stressful nor overwhelming. It's a great class!
very good - past paced, lots of work but a steady workflow. you need to be self-motivated to take it but the rewards are high.
Yes. It's a little all over the place. Not as well taught as intro chinese, but enjoyable.
